query: What methods are available to control disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms?
relevant_summary: A study in Scotland found that using a fallowing system resulted in lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon (1026). However, another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages with a fallowing system (1026). In Scotland, a replicated study found that salmon fed a probiotic before being exposed to four different disease-causing bacteria had increased survival over a 28-day period compared to controls (732). A replicated, controlled study in Norway found that the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when they were fed a diet of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein (732). Adding beta-glucans to the diet further decreased lice infection levels by 28% compared to controls (732). The same study found that adding mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function (732). Two studies in Ireland on the use of cleaner wrasse as a natural control agent for sea lice had mixed results. One controlled study found that corkwing and goldsinny cleaner wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments for controlling lice infestation (738). In contrast, a replicated, controlled study found that rockcook cleaner wrasse were not effective at preventing lice outbreaks (738).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "732",
  "action_title": "Use of probiotics and immunostimulants",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. Adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}

query: How do plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal compare in terms of their effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates in Norway?
relevant_summary: Evidence for the effects of replacing fish meal with bacterial protein on salmon growth is mixed. Two replicated, controlled studies in Norway found similar growth rates in salmon fed diets with up to 25% bacterial protein compared to a 100% fish meal diet, but lower growth rates with 50% bacterial protein (918). Another replicated, controlled study in Norway reported higher growth rates in salmon fed diets with 18% and 36% bacterial protein compared to the control (918). For plant-based proteins, six studies in Norway, Scotland, and the USA found decreased growth rates in salmon when plant-based proteins were included in the feed (924). However, three studies from Norway, Canada, and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets (924). Four replicated, controlled studies from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets, while two controlled studies from Norway found similar final body weights (924). Two studies in Norway found lowered feeding efficiency with plant-based diets, whereas one study in Norway found increased feeding efficiency (924).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal for Atlantic salmon growth"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "924",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

query: Which interventions appear most effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease?
relevant_summary: Two controlled studies in Iceland and Norway investigating disease-causing bacteria reported higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated salmon (733). Additionally, two controlled studies in Australia and Canada found that vaccinated salmon had a higher survival rate when infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease (733). For salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia, two controlled studies in Norway reported similar results (733). A replicated, controlled study in Norway observed increased survival levels in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis when the fish were bred for high resistance to the disease (735). In Scotland, a study found lower numbers of lice on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system (1026), but another study in Australia reported no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages with a fallowing system (1026).

{
  "action_id": "733",
  "action_title": "Use vaccinations",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups. This was post exposure to the disease-causing bacteria, Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri, respectively.
Two controlled studies in Australia and Canadia reported higher survival in salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease, post vaccination.
Two controlled studies in Norway reported similar results for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia."
}

query: What are the documented effects of using plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland?
relevant_summary: Six studies in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that including plant-based proteins in feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon, while three studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates (924). Four studies from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets, while two studies from Norway found similar final body weights (924). Two studies from Norway found lowered feeding efficiency, one study in Norway found increased feeding efficiency, and two studies in Canada and Scotland found similar levels of feeding efficiency (924). Digestibility of feed was found to be lower in two studies, while two other studies in Scotland and Norway found similar levels of digestibility between plant-based and fish meal diets (924). Survival and appetite were not affected by either diet type. However, the morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. The condition of the salmon was increased in one study but reduced in two other studies (924).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture in Norway and Scotland"}

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One replicated study in Norway found growth rates were higher in fish fed diets containing vegetable oil.  One replicated, controlled study found salmon growth rates were both lower and higher in vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets, dependant on family genetics.
Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Norway found similar average final body weights between groups of salmon fed both fish oil and vegetable oil diets.
Three studies (two replicated, one controlled) in Norway and Scotland found that the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected oil source within diets.
A study in Norway found that oil source in diets did not affect salmon broodstock fecundity levels, egg weights, fertility rates, as well as the weights and development of resultant fry.
One replicated Norwegian study found that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to the fish oil diet. One replicated, controlled study found high levels of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to diets containing rapeseed oil.
A replicated, controlled study in Scotland found salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls within flesh, compared with diets containing fish oil.
A replicated study in Norway found that fresh, frozen and smoked salmon flesh from fish fed vegetable oil- and fish oil-based diets had similar levels of gaping, texture and liquid holding capacity. Pigment concentration was lower in vegetable oil diets."
}

query: What are the non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Two studies in Ireland investigating the use of cleaner wrasse to control sea lice on salmon farms reported mixed effects, with one study finding that corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments, while the other found that rockcook cleaner wrasse were ineffective (738). A replicated, controlled study in Norway found that salmon kept in low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting had fewer lice than those in more intense artificial light (741). A study in Scotland recorded lower numbers of lice on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system (1026).

relevant_summary: A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system (1026). A study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used (1026).

query: How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?
relevant_summary: One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon that were fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica compared to a control diet containing fishmeal (920). Two replicated studies in Norway found similar final weight gain between salmon that were fed diets containing fish meal only or a krill meal substitute (916). When the krill were de-shelled, growth rates were closer to salmon fed fish meal, compared to leaving the krill whole (916). One controlled, randomised, replicated study from Scotland showed that fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative proteins (922).

query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway for using alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary:
Three replicated, controlled studies in Norway found no difference in the growth rate or histology of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing genetically modified (GM) soybeans compared to non-GM soybeans [928]. One controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon fed diets with the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica and those on a fishmeal control diet [920].

For plant-based proteins, the evidence is more varied. Some studies in Norway indicated that including plant-based proteins in feed led to decreased growth rates, while others found similar growth rates compared to fishmeal diets [924]. Similarly, some Norwegian studies found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based diets, while others reported similar final body weights to those on fishmeal diets [924]. Two replicated, controlled studies in Norway showed lower feeding efficiency with plant-based proteins, but another replicated study found increased feeding efficiency [924]. Digestibility was also variable, with one Norwegian study showing lower digestibility for plant-based diets and another showing similar levels to fishmeal diets [924]. Two studies also noted that while survival and appetite were unaffected, the morphology of the distal intestine was altered in salmon fed plant-based diets [924].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets in Norway"}

query: What are the effects of altering the physical environment of salmon cages, such as their size or lighting, on salmon health in aquaculture?
relevant_summary: A replicated study in Australia showed that salmon housed in larger cages exhibited lower levels of amoebic gill disease when compared to salmon in smaller cages (742).

query: How do different non-chemical water-based treatments, such as fallowing and freshwater bathing, compare in their reported effectiveness for specific diseases in salmon?
relevant_summary: A study in Scotland reported lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system (1026). A separate study in Australia, however, found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system was used (1026). Two studies in Australia provide mixed evidence for the effectiveness of freshwater bathing in reducing amoebic gill disease (739). One study found a reduction in the number of amoebae on salmon gills that persisted for up to 10 days after bathing, while a replicated, controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in the gills of treated and untreated salmon (739).

query: Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?
relevant_summary:
Two replicated studies in Norway demonstrated that salmon fed diets with krill meal substitute showed similar final weight gain as those on a fish meal-only diet (916). The feed conversion ratios were also similar between the krill and fish meal diets (916).

The evidence for bacterial protein is mixed (918). Two controlled studies in Norway found that diets with up to 25% bacterial protein resulted in similar growth rates to a 100% fish meal diet, but a diet with 50% bacterial protein led to lower growth rates (918). Conversely, another Norwegian study reported higher growth rates in salmon fed diets containing 18% and 36% bacterial protein compared to the control group (918).

For plant-based proteins, the findings are also varied (924). While six studies indicated that plant-based proteins decreased growth rates in salmon, three other studies found similar growth rates compared to fish meal diets (924). Regarding final body weight, four studies noted a reduction with plant-based diets, but two controlled studies found similar final body weights to fish meal diets (924).

Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

query: What is the evidence that integrated aquaculture systems or constructing artificial reefs can mitigate the environmental impacts of salmon farms?
relevant_summary:
One study in Canada found that blue mussels absorbed waste from a salmon farm, a replicated, controlled study in the USA reported greater growth of scallops grown next to fish farms, and a replicated, controlled study in Scotland reported enhanced algal growth when placed adjacent to fish farms [932]. However, one study in Spain found no evidence that oysters and mussels were feeding on fish farm waste [932]. No studies were found that evaluated the effects on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations of using species from more than one level of a food web in aquaculture systems [2195].

One controlled study in the Red Sea found no difference in sediment carbon at artificial reef sites adjacent to or away from fish farms, but reports that the artificial reefs at both sites were colonized with various species with the potential to remove organic compounds from fish farm effluents [934]. One controlled study in the Mediterranean Sea found that an artificial reef located under aquaculture cages had a similar invertebrate community composition to artificial reefs located at sites without aquaculture cages, and one controlled study in the Gulf of Aqaba found that an artificial reef located at an aquaculture site had similar invertebrate biomass growing on it compared to an artificial reef located at a site without aquaculture cages [2260]. We found no studies that evaluated the effects of locating artificial reefs near aquaculture systems to act as biofilters on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations [2196].

  "action_title": "Integrated aquaculture systems",

A study in Canada found that blue mussels absorbed waste from a salmon farm.
A replicated, controlled study in Scotland reported enhanced algal growth when placed adjacent to fish farms. 
One study in Spain found no evidence that oyster and mussels were feeding on fish farm waste."
}

We found no studies that evaluated the effects of using species from more than one level of a food web in aquaculture systems on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations.

 
‘We found no studies’ means that we have not yet found any studies that have directly evaluated this intervention during our systematic journal and report searches. Therefore, we have no evidence to indicate whether or not the intervention has any desirable or harmful effects."
}

  "action_id": "2260",
  "action_title": "Locate artificial reefs near aquaculture systems to benefit from nutrient run-offs",

Two studies examined the effects of locating artificial reefs near aquaculture systems to benefit from nutrient run-offs on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations. One study was in the Gulf of Aqaba (Israel and Jordan), and one in the Mediterranean Sea (Spain).

 
COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Overall community composition (1 study): One controlled study in the Mediterranean Sea found that an artificial reef located under aquaculture cages had similar invertebrate community composition to artificial reefs located at sites without aquaculture cages.

POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Overall abundance (1 study): One controlled study in the Gulf of Aqaba found that an artificial reef located at an aquaculture site had similar invertebrate biomass growing on it compared to an artificial reef located at a site without aquaculture cages."
}

{
  "action_id": "2196",
  "action_title": "Locate artificial reefs near aquaculture systems (and vice versa) to act as biofilters",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

We found no studies that evaluated the effects of locating artificial reefs near aquaculture systems to act as biofilters on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations.

 
‘We found no studies’ means that we have not yet found any studies that have directly evaluated this intervention during our systematic journal and report searches. Therefore, we have no evidence to indicate whether or not the intervention has any desirable or harmful effects."
}

No studies were found that evaluated the effects on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations of using species from more than one level of a food web in aquaculture systems [2195].\n\nOne controlled study in the Red Sea found no difference in sediment carbon at artificial reef sites adjacent to or away from fish farms, but reports that the artificial reefs at both sites were colonized with various species with the potential to remove organic compounds from fish farm effluents [934]. query: How do physical interventions like aerobic training and altering cage size affect the health and survival of farmed Atlantic salmon?
relevant_summary: A study in Norway indicated that aerobic training could enhance the survival rates of salmon suffering from infectious pancreatic necrosis, with interval training proving to be more effective than continuous training [740]. In addition, a study conducted in Australia revealed that salmon housed in larger cages exhibited reduced levels of amoebic gill disease when compared to those in smaller cages [742].

tools_called.args: {"query":"How do physical interventions like aerobic training and altering cage size affect the health and survival of farmed Atlantic salmon?","summary":"A study in Norway indicated that aerobic training could enhance the survival rates of salmon suffering from infectious pancreatic necrosis, with interval training proving to be more effective than continuous training [740]. In addition, a study conducted in Australia revealed that salmon housed in larger cages exhibited reduced levels of amoebic gill disease when compared to those in smaller cages [742].","action_ids":["740","742"]}

query: What are the observed effects on salmon growth and flesh quality when replacing fish oil with plant-based or other animal-based oils in their diet?
relevant_summary: When replacing fish oil with plant-based oils in salmon diets, three replicated studies in Norway found similar growth rates, while one study reported higher growth rates with vegetable oil, and another found that growth rates depended on family genetics [926]. Two replicated studies in Norway also found similar average final body weights between salmon fed fish oil and vegetable oil diets [926]. In terms of flesh quality, three studies in Norway and Scotland noted that the fatty acid profile of the salmon flesh reflected the dietary oil source [926]. Furthermore, a replicated, controlled study in Scotland revealed that salmon on vegetable oil-based diets had lower levels of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls in their flesh [926]. A Norwegian study also indicated that while flesh quality attributes like gaping, texture, and liquid holding capacity were similar between fish fed vegetable oil and fish oil diets, pigment concentration was lower in the vegetable oil group [926]. For other animal-based oils, one controlled, replicated study in Canada found no difference in oxygen consumption or swimming speed of Atlantic salmon fed diets with anchovy oil versus alternative lipid sources [922].

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "926",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative oil source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Three replicated studies (two controlled) in Norway found growth rates were similar in salmon that were fed diets containing fish oil and vegetable oil. One replicated study in Norway found growth rates were higher in fish fed diets containing vegetable oil.  One replicated, controlled study found salmon growth rates were both lower and higher in vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets, dependant on family genetics.
Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Norway found similar average final body weights between groups of salmon fed both fish oil and vegetable oil diets.
Three studies (two replicated, one controlled) in Norway and Scotland found that the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected oil source within diets.
A study in Norway found that oil source in diets did not affect salmon broodstock fecundity levels, egg weights, fertility rates, as well as the weights and development of resultant fry.
One replicated Norwegian study found that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to the fish oil diet. One replicated, controlled study found high levels of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to diets containing rapeseed oil.
A replicated, controlled study in Scotland found salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls within flesh, compared with diets containing fish oil.
A replicated study in Norway found that fresh, frozen and smoked salmon flesh from fish fed vegetable oil- and fish oil-based diets had similar levels of gaping, texture and liquid holding capacity. Pigment concentration was lower in vegetable oil diets."
}

Two replicated studies in Norway also found similar average final body weights between salmon fed fish oil and vegetable oil diets [926]. In terms of flesh quality, three studies in Norway and Scotland noted that the fatty acid profile of the salmon flesh reflected the dietary oil source [926]. Furthermore, a replicated, controlled study in Scotland revealed that salmon on vegetable oil-based diets had lower levels of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls in their flesh [926]. A Norwegian study also indicated that while flesh quality attributes like gaping, texture, and liquid holding capacity were similar between fish fed vegetable oil and fish oil diets, pigment concentration was lower in the vegetable oil group [926]. For other animal-based oils, one controlled, replicated study in Canada found no difference in oxygen consumption or swimming speed of Atlantic salmon fed diets with anchovy oil versus alternative lipid sources [922]."}

query: What is the evidence regarding the effect of using genetically modified ingredients or dietary supplements on the growth of Atlantic salmon?
relevant_summary: Three controlled, replicated studies in Norway found no difference in the growth rate of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing either genetically modified (GM) or non-GM soybeans (928). One randomised, replicated, controlled study in Norway also found no differences in the histology of fish fed diets containing either GM or non-GM soybeans (928). One controlled, replicated study in Australia found no difference in weight gain of Atlantic salmon with and without dietary supplementation of phytase and phosphate, while another controlled, replicated study in Australia found that fish fed diets supplemented with phytase had greater final weights than those given no supplement (930). A controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain of salmon that were fed diets with or without taurine supplementation (930).

query: What is the evidence from European studies for using vaccinations or probiotics to improve the survival rates of farmed Atlantic salmon?
relevant_summary: Two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups after exposure to disease-causing bacteria (733). Two controlled studies in Norway reported similar results for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia (733). One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls (732). A replicated, controlled study in Norway found that adding beta-glucans to the diet of salmon decreased lice infection levels by 28% compared to controls (732). The same study in Norway found that the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls (732).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"vaccinations or probiotics for farmed Atlantic salmon survival"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "733",
  "action_title": "Use vaccinations",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups. This was post exposure to the disease-causing bacteria, Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri, respectively.
Two controlled studies in Australia and Canadia reported higher survival in salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease, post vaccination.
Two controlled studies in Norway reported similar results for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia."
}

{
  "action_id": "732",
  "action_title": "Use of probiotics and immunostimulants",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. Adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}

relevant_summary: A study in Scotland showed that fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative proteins [922]. An experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica and a control diet with fishmeal [920].

query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway regarding the effectiveness of non-dietary interventions for improving farmed Atlantic salmon health and survival?
relevant_summary: A controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain for salmon fed diets with or without taurine supplementation [930]. Two controlled studies in Norway reported higher survival rates in salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia compared to unvaccinated groups. Another controlled study in Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon post-exposure to the disease-causing bacteria Yersinia ruckeri [733]. A replicated, controlled study in Norway found that the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when they were fed a diet of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. The addition of beta-glucans to this diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% [732].

query: What actions are available to manage the waste products, such as excess nutrients and sludge, from salmon aquaculture operations?
relevant_summary: A study in Canada found that blue mussels absorbed waste from a salmon farm (932). Additionally, a replicated, controlled study in Scotland reported enhanced algal growth when placed adjacent to fish farms (932). One replicated, controlled study in the USA reported greater growth of scallops grown next to fish farms (932). However, one study in Spain found no evidence that oysters and mussels were feeding on fish farm waste (932)

query: What is the evidence from Australian studies on the effectiveness of different husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon?
relevant_summary: One Australian study found that implementing a fallowing system had no effect on salmon mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease (1026). Evidence for freshwater bathing as a treatment for Amoebic Gill Disease is inconclusive, with one study showing a reduction in amoebae on salmon gills for up to 10 days post-treatment, and another replicated study finding no difference between treated and untreated salmon (739). A separate replicated study in Australia found that salmon housed in larger cages had lower levels of Amoebic Gill Disease than those in smaller cages (742).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon in Australia"}

A separate replicated study in Australia found that salmon housed in larger cages had lower levels of Amoebic Gill Disease than those in smaller cages (742).","query":"What is the evidence from Australian studies on the effectiveness of different husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon?"}

query: Beyond growth rates, what other biological effects have been observed in salmon fed diets with krill or plant-based proteins instead of fish meal?
relevant_summary: Salmon fed diets with krill meal substitute instead of fish meal had similar feed conversion ratios (916). The number of aerobic bacteria in the hindgut of salmon fed krill meal was higher and the bacterial flora composition was different (916). For salmon fed plant-based proteins, some studies found reduced final body weights, while others found similar weights compared to fish meal diets (924). Feeding efficiency was reported to be lower in some studies, higher in one, and similar in others (924). Digestibility of feed components was found to be lower in two studies but similar in two other studies (924). Survival rates and appetite were not affected in two studies (924). However, the morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two studies of salmon fed plant-based proteins (924). The condition of the salmon was increased in one study but reduced in two other studies (924).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"biological effects of replacing fish meal in salmon diets with krill or plant-based proteins"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "924",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

query: What non-chemical methods can be used to manage pests and biofouling on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system (1026). A trial in Tasmania found that the sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles (1027). However, a study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used (1026).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"non-chemical pest and biofouling management in salmon farms"}

query: What factors influence the success of non-pesticide methods for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Two studies in Ireland found mixed effects of cleaner wrasse on sea lice numbers infesting salmon. One controlled study found corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were as effective at controlling lice infestation as chemical treatments. One replicated, controlled study found rockcook cleaner wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks (738). A replicated, controlled study in Norway reported lower numbers of lice on salmon kept in low intensity artificial light or natural lighting. The more intense the artificial light was, the higher the number of lice found on fish (741). A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system. Another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used (1026).

query: In Norway, how do different plant-based feed alternatives, such as vegetable oils versus plant proteins, affect salmon growth and body composition?
relevant_summary:
In Norway, studies on plant-based proteins showed varied effects on salmon growth, with some indicating decreased growth rates [924] while others found similar rates to fish meal diets [924]. Four studies in Norway and Scotland noted reduced final body weights with plant-protein diets, whereas two Norwegian studies found no difference [924]. Feeding efficiency was reported to be lower in two Norwegian studies, but another in the same country found it to be higher [924]. The morphology of the distal intestine was altered in salmon fed diets containing plant-based proteins in two studies [924].

Regarding vegetable oils, three Norwegian studies found that salmon growth rates were similar when fed diets with either fish oil or vegetable oil [926]. Another study in Norway observed higher growth rates in salmon fed vegetable oil diets [926]. Final body weights were found to be similar in two Norwegian studies comparing vegetable oil and fish oil diets [926]. The fatty acid profile of salmon flesh was found to reflect the oil source in the diets in three studies in Norway and Scotland [926]. A Norwegian study found that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to those on a fish oil diet [926].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"plant-based feed alternatives for salmon in Norway"}

{

Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

  "action_title": "Use an alternative oil source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Three replicated studies (two controlled) in Norway found growth rates were similar in salmon that were fed diets containing fish oil and vegetable oil. One replicated study in Norway found growth rates were higher in fish fed diets containing vegetable oil.  One replicated, controlled study found salmon growth rates were both lower and higher in vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets, dependant on family genetics.
Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Norway found similar average final body weights between groups of salmon fed both fish oil and vegetable oil diets.
Three studies (two replicated, one controlled) in Norway and Scotland found that the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected oil source within diets.
A study in Norway found that oil source in diets did not affect salmon broodstock fecundity levels, egg weights, fertility rates, as well as the weights and development of resultant fry.
One replicated Norwegian study found that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to the fish oil diet. One replicated, controlled study found high levels of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to diets containing rapeseed oil.
A replicated, controlled study in Scotland found salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls within flesh, compared with diets containing fish oil.
A replicated study in Norway found that fresh, frozen and smoked salmon flesh from fish fed vegetable oil- and fish oil-based diets had similar levels of gaping, texture and liquid holding capacity. Pigment concentration was lower in vegetable oil diets."
}

Feeding efficiency was reported to be lower in two Norwegian studies, but another in the same country found it to be higher [924]. The morphology of the distal intestine was altered in salmon fed diets containing plant-based proteins in two studies [924].\n\nRegarding vegetable oils, three Norwegian studies found that salmon growth rates were similar when fed diets with either fish oil or vegetable oil [926]. Another study in Norway observed higher growth rates in salmon fed vegetable oil diets [926]. Final body weights were found to be similar in two Norwegian studies comparing vegetable oil and fish oil diets [926]. The fatty acid profile of salmon flesh was found to reflect the oil source in the diets in three studies in Norway and Scotland [926]. A Norwegian study found that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to those on a fish oil diet [926].","action_ids":["924","926"],"query":"In Norway, how do different plant-based feed alternatives, such as vegetable oils versus plant proteins, affect salmon growth and body composition?"}

query: What are the documented effects, both positive and negative, of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary: Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon (924). Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets (924). Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets (924). Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets (924). Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets (924). Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types (924). Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal (924). Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway (924). Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets (924). However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins (924). Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies (924).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effects of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets"}

query: What does the evidence say about using probiotics, immunostimulants, or specific training to improve salmon survival against diseases?
relevant_summary: A replicated study in Scotland found that salmon fed a probiotic before being exposed to four different disease-causing bacteria had increased survival over a 28-day period compared to controls (732). In a replicated, controlled study in Norway, the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when they were fed a diet of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. The addition of beta-glucans to this diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared to controls (732). The same study found that the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis when compared to controls (732). A randomised, replicated, controlled study in Norway discovered higher survival rates in salmon that had been exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis if they had undergone aerobic training. The study also found that interval training was more effective than continuous training (740).

tools_called.args: {"offset":0,"query_string":"probiotics, immunostimulants, or specific training for salmon","k":3}

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. Adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}

query: Based on studies in Australia, which husbandry practices have shown mixed or limited success in managing diseases and environmental impacts from salmon farming?
relevant_summary: A study in Australia indicated that establishing fallowing to reduce parasites and diseases in salmon farming showed limited success, as it found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system was used (1026). This contrasts with a study in Scotland that recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system (1026).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "733",
  "action_title": "Use vaccinations",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups. This was post exposure to the disease-causing bacteria, Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri, respectively.
Two controlled studies in Australia and Canadia reported higher survival in salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease, post vaccination.
Two controlled studies in Norway reported similar results for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia."
}
